text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here Internet's busy
piaced music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new Cuellar Talk LP Mir
which is the latest sophomore LP from a
Norwegian metal outfit
I reviewed him a while back on the
channel back when I had the tree intros
really getting nostalgic missing the
tree I just got to do this
fella talk yeah that might just be the
way we do things from now on again this
band's full-length debut LP came out in
2010 and at the time it turned a lot of
heads in the metal world thanks to some
pretty hefty endorsements from artists
like Dave Grohl some fantastic
production from converges Kurt blew some
beautiful cover art from John Baisley of
Baroness and of course touring with
torch and converge helped along with
some of their popularity in the States
too
but more than anything what grabbed
attention for capella talk was their
sound a combination of vocals that felt
inspired by black metal as well as punk
music the tremolo picked leads and the
minor chords strummed quickly as well as
blast beats totally came from the world
of black metal and on top of that a ton
of melody coming from the worlds of
heavy metal as well as rock and roll not
only was this LP awesome had a lot of
detail and a lot of replay value but the
enjoyment of it is so damn instantaneous
it's infectious now the band is back
again with this sophomore full-length
mirror and they are catchy ER and more
melodic than ever and I can understand
them wanting to turn up the melody on
this LP turn up the hooks because they
certainly are what kind of separated
them from a lot of other metal acts in
2010 and as a result I do think this
album is maybe a little less extreme a
little less pummeling and aggressive but
it's not like the album goes so far into
accessibility that it loses its punch
even as the band lays some cleanly some
vocals over some very just harsh black
metal chords and the opening track here
and on the song brain bren which was one
of the lead singles from this LP and has
an incredibly melodic chorus the
production on this LP overall feels
pretty much the same which isn't
necessarily a bad thing on the last
record and this record the guitars the
drums the vocals all sound really
muscular they're clean they're BBB beefy
there's a lot of clarity there and what
I find to be so awesome on this album is
that the production complements all of
the influences all the ingredients
this LP so well of course the band is
working with Kurt Balu again and he with
the group makes sure that the black
metal parts are are fast and pummeling
that the guitar chords being strummed
really faster sharp they make sure that
the rock-and-roll and heavy metal riffs
have a nice groove to them and that the
rich and melodic solos and leads just
shine out past the rest of the
distortion and the overpowering drums
nothing really gets lost in translation
as the band speeds up to play something
more in a hardcore punk vein and the
acoustic guitar which the group uses a
lot more on this album feels really warm
and sticks out nicely so Feller talk on
this new LP their style they're
recording pretty much stays intact it's
still really good but in terms of
songwriting and performance I would say
the band delivers once again
impressively though some people can
definitely say that this LP feels like a
sequel to the debut there are some clear
moments of ambition on this LP not only
does it have a really big introduction a
clearer and more interesting flow to the
tracks some really long songs as well
one that's almost nine minutes the
opening track on this LP starts off with
sort of an ominous drone that builds up
the guitars are just rising and rising
and rising in the band eventually breaks
into this black metal stick and there
are all these really righteous melodies
attached to these black metal chords it
feels so just uplifting in a way the
second track on this LP to play places
more major chord melodies against black
metal chords and drums of course there
are plenty of rock-and-roll riffs
throughout this track and the very end
of the song there's this awesome guitar
flourish ending the track out that feels
like I'm listening to the finish of some
kind of Southern Fried rock-and-roll
tune something like Creedence Clearwater
Revival inspired in a way it's moments
like this that make me feel like yeah
the band really works with a combination
of different things but they somehow do
them all justice and bring them all
together in a way that doesn't feel that
corny maybe it might feel like a sort of
a bastardization to a purist for any of
these genres but the accurate melodic
references and the playing definitely
shows that valor talk has at least a
passionate appreciation for a lot of the
things that they're emulating now there
are some moments on this LP like the
track trip Han which honestly don't
really bring that much novelty to the
table and just kind of feel like I
really heard this from cellar talk
before and even though overall I do
think valor talk stays in their comfort
zone on this LP they still managed to
bring just a little bit of extra variety
like the tractor which in the middle of
it all of these guitars fly in they have
sort of a middle-eastern Egyptian vibe
to them and go on a pretty awesome
instrumental interlude right before the
band kind of heads back into yet another
black metal inspired verse now toward
the end of this LP there's three tracks
right next to each other and they are
kind of the lengthy trifecta on this
album all of the long songs just bunched
together and they range from this six to
almost nine minute range and these
tracks on the album might actually be my
favorite I'm not going to spoil every
single detail in all of these songs but
it's here that I really feel like feller
talk proves that they're not just a
one-trick pony in terms of writing a
short song that just kind of hits you
and runs and throws a few catchy hooks
at you because a lot of these songs just
build up epicly with black metal
inspired interludes noisy solos quieter
parts loud climaxes and all these tracks
especially the longest of the three just
stay engaging throughout the closing
track on this LP is titled after the
band it's a bit of an anthem and maybe
the catchiest on the entire LP it really
sort of brings all the elements to the
table that define valor talk as a
musical act it sort of has this edginess
of hardcore punk and black metal but is
just so rich with melody and an awesome
hook that it feels like it's almost got
an arena rock kind of vibe to it at this
point in terms of the sound that the
band has on this album Mir is not
incredibly revolutionary but I got to
say color talk did hell of a performance
a hell of a recording some really good
songwriting and they put together a
really interesting arc for this album
resulting in an album
I think is maybe a little more cinematic
for me personally this album is on par
in nearly every way with the debut
though I do think that some people may
not necessarily jump on top of it as
excitedly because at this point Fela
talk is no longer a fresh face in music
or the metal world in general I'm
feeling a decent discriminate on this
thing if you've given it a listen what
did you think of it did you love it did
you hate it why what do you think I
should review next and yeah that's it
Fowler talked Muir forever
[Music]
[Music]
